pretzel.author: Emily H.
pretzel.review:
Loved it!

4-5 taps of German beer. A little pricey but oh-so-good. Bartenders were very nice. Great that they accept credit cards. 

We managed to find a table pretty easily on a Friday afternoon (4th of July weekend). One of the girls in our group ordered the pretzel knot with cheese and it looked SO good. We were getting dinner at Suppenkuche later on that night or else I would've ordered some food. It all looked quite good.

Will come back again! It was so cold this time, but maybe next time I'll pay Smitten a visit too!

excerpts: Don't forget about the regular pretzel!
The spicy mustard with horseradish is to die for!
pretzel.author: Vanessa L.
pretzel.review:
Um, hello! I don't know why this place doesn't have a perfect score! It is awesome!  We rode our bikes down here and arriving at 5:30, were able to score an end of a table and some great beer!  Don't forget about the regular pretzel!  The spicy mustard with horseradish is to die for! I can't wait to go back!

The blankets make it!  SF can get cold in a blink of an eye but their blankets make everything alright!

excerpts: BUT somehow you can pay cash and get a pretzel.
pretzel.author: Cody C.
pretzel.review:
The idea is great but execution is poor. The beer is the best part, quality beer and you can get a liter glass, great!

But with only 4 taps operated by 2 servers the line quickly gets crazy and makes a 35min wait for a beer. 

They need to have 4 times the number of taps and servers.

While the beer line is long and snaking outside, the food line is non-existent. Then there is a poor decision that all food must be ordered from the bar (the big line). BUT somehow you can pay cash and get a pretzel. Huh?!?!

One should be able to order food from the food cart without having to do it through the bar. Thats just plain silly.

I want to like this place but management needs to get their act together cause otherwise its a poor experience.

excerpts: I was disappointed in this place; it was way overpriced ($5 for a PRETZEL?, $8 for a beer?), way overhyped (line to get in!), and food and drink that is much better done elsewhere.
pretzel.author: Paul S.
pretzel.review:
I was disappointed in this place; it was way overpriced ($5 for a PRETZEL?, $8 for a beer?), way overhyped (line to get in!), and food and drink that is much better done elsewhere.

Oh you just finished your beer at Biergarten and want another one?  Well, you gotta get up from your table, then stand in a long line for about 10-15 minutes just to buy your ass another beer.  There is an ARMY of staff waiting around to snatch your empty food baskets as SOON as you finish eating, but they apparently can't bring you a fresh beer (like they can in a REAL German biergarten).  Hey, let me finish the last bits of kraut before you yank that basket away, will ya?

They have a handful (3-4) of German beers on tap that you can get in massive-sized glasses if you want (bitte, $15!).  Toronado and Rosamunde Sausage Grill (the one on Mission) have the same or better selection of these types of German beers.  Even The Uptown on Capp St. usually has some nice Paulaners.

As for the food, the sausage was undercooked (still pink on the inside!) and didn't even come with a bun -- for $9!.  Rosamunde Sausage Grill's sausage is ten times better at 2/3 the price.  Heck, Rosamunde's BUN is by itself better than anything I had at Biergarten.

Aside from offering opportunity to drink outside like Zeitgeist, which frankly does everything much better (upscale people are just afraid of the bathrooms there), this place offers nothing.  This is just another overhyped pseudo foodie place in SF.  

You can find me at Rosamunde when I want a German sausage and a German beer (yes, they often even have Kostrizter Schwartzbier).  It's better (the kraut is even better, nicely seasoned with juniper berries), cheaper, and less hassle, and no wait to get in, no ridiculous 15-20 minute line to buy another beer.   The Mission location even has outside seating.

Biergarten is proof that you can take mediocre food, a handful of common German beers that are available elsewhere, overprice it all by 50% and STILL have people lining up because you put the whole thing outside -- on a slab of parking lot asphalt surrounded by a chainlink fence.  "Oh, we have a biergarten in SF... how Europeannnnnn!"

excerpts: The pretzel I had was fantastic, love that it's served with both mustard and horseradish.
And the beer?
Pretty damn good.
pretzel.author: phil h.
pretzel.review:
Once they work out all the kinks, Biergarten has a chance to be my favorite al fresco watering hole in the city. 

Now about those kinks...sure, the place is brand new, has been all over Thrillist, Daily Candy, Eater SF, Urban Daddy, Tabblehopper, Yelp, etc. etc. And opening weekend happened to be one of the nicest days of the year. So we did the smart thing and hopped in line at 2:40. We were inside right at 3pm and had no problem grabbing a table, though by the time the dust settled the line to get beer was almost as long as the line to get in the door.

Couple suggestions - maybe have an auxiliary bar set up to sell bottles of beer for those that don't want to wait for the selections out of the taps. Also, it would be great to be able to order food without waiting in that same beer line...it's possible to order pretzels from the food pick up window, why not just order all food there?

That being said, we really loved the place. Tables are communal and encourage chatting with your neighbors. The pretzel I had was fantastic, love that it's served with both mustard and horseradish. And the beer? Pretty damn good.

excerpts: We got the banana knot, and it was delicious - a pretzel with honey and banana (and maybe something else that I can't recall right now).
It was delicious!
The best part - everyone really just seems like they are having a great time!
pretzel.author: Su P.
pretzel.review:
This little not so hidden beer garden is definitely a place to be. With long lines for a beer, you'll have to check it out. Don't fret, though, you can get 1L beer, so the wait is well worth it. The 4-5 different choices is certain to have an option for the hoppy, light, dark, and fruity loving beer go-ers. It's like $16-20 for a 1L beer, but that's almost 3 normal beers!

The crowd is anyone and everyone - you'll see hipsters, bros, older couples, college couples, etc. Everyone cozying up on the benches when it's packed. It's a great place to people watch the folks on their way to get some ice cream, biking through Hayes Valley, and even families in that makeshift playground. 

We got the banana knot, and it was delicious - a pretzel with honey and banana (and maybe something else that I can't recall right now). It was delicious!
 
The best part - everyone really just seems like they are having a great time!

excerpts: We arrived right at 3pm when the Biergarten opened and waited in line for about 30 minutes to get in, then waited another 20-30 minutes for a beer and a pretzel.
pretzel.author: Sarah Z.
pretzel.review:
This place just opened so I'm cutting them some slack because: 
1.) I love the concept and applaud them for getting this off  the ground 
2.) I think they will work out the kinks 
3.) I hope this will create opportunities for more restaurants/bars like this one

We arrived right at 3pm when the Biergarten opened and waited in line for about 30 minutes to get in, then waited another 20-30 minutes for a beer and a pretzel.  Kind of a long wait, but the place is new and I'm hoping they will work out a better way to handle the flow of people in/out/serving beers.

The staff was beyond friendly and a bit apologetic about getting things going with the new space.  Totally understandable.  The beers were big and delicious and the pretzels really hit the spot.  I did not have a sausage, but will definitely go back for one.  

It's not uber cheap (two giant beers came to approx. $21) but I guess that's just what giant beers go for in Hayes Valley.  

The atmosphere is still a little bleak - it's basically a chain link fence around a parking lot with picnic tables and a few trees for shade.  However, it looks like vines are being grown on the fence and the trees will fill out.  Lots of potential!

excerpts:
On to the hugely disappointing snacks:
I was looking forward to having a nice, warm German pretzel.
What I got in return for my $5 was a COLD seeded pretzel with dollops of mustard and nostril-searing horseradish.
pretzel.author: Patrick H.
pretzel.review:
Go for the bier, stay for the outdoor drinking experience. But eat elsewhere. 

Let me explain...

The beer choices are good and you can get them in 1/2 or 1 Litre sizes, but you'll have to wait in a long line before getting to quench your thirst. The people taking your order are friendly, answer your questions, and don't rush you despite the line that keeps growing behind you (it takes a while to pour a litre of beer!).

Once you have your beer in hand, find a picnic table, kick back, and get merry.

And if you happen to get hungry, I'd visit the food trucks parked around the corner before buying food here again. On to the hugely disappointing snacks:
I was looking forward to having a nice, warm German pretzel. What I got in return for my $5 was a COLD seeded pretzel with dollops of mustard and nostril-searing horseradish. F that.

Still hungry, I ordered a brat & sauerkraut for $9. Tasty, but no bun so it wasn't as filling as I was hoping. Hey, at least the brat was hot. Still, $9 for a brat is kinda crazy. Is there a ballgame going on here? They must be made from organic, virgin, nitrite-free, vegan-diet pork to justify it.

Given their overhead (or lack thereof), I'd expect lower prices across the board. But since the crowds keep on coming, I doubt they'll change anything.

excerpts: I shared a large beer with my boyfriend and a brat basket, which is two bratwursts and one "pretzel" (pretty small if you ask me) for $18.
Two hotdogs and a ball of bread for nearly $20?
Luckily we weren't too hungry.
I wouldn't order this dish again.
pretzel.author: Carolyn N.
pretzel.review:
Beer -- good but they ran out of one kind.  They only have 3 kinds!  Also, it was expensive.  The smaller size of beer (which is still plenty big) is $8.  The large size is $15.  

I shared a large beer with my boyfriend and a brat basket, which is two bratwursts and one "pretzel" (pretty small if you ask me) for $18.  Two hotdogs and a ball of bread for nearly $20?  Luckily we weren't too hungry.  I wouldn't order this dish again.  The sauerkraut was good . . . 

Best thing about this place is the outdoor tables.  It has cute white lights that brighten it up at night and give it a fun atmosphere.  It was pretty busy for a Wednesday when I went.  Crowd was late 20s.

I would go back here only for the beer, not for the food.  But it is a unique option when Suppenkuche is too busy to seat you.  And, they bring the food to the table (they give you a number when you order) which is a nice touch.

excerpts: I had the 2 sausages combo with pretzel for $18.
The 1L beer is about $10.
Sausages was ok
, pretzel was good.
pretzel.author: Andrew I.
pretzel.review:
Actual rating: 3.75 / 5 stars

This place is an awesome place to go to.... if you bring all your friends with you and drink lots of beer with lots of obnoxious people. Nice place, since it's closed off across a park with lot of good stores around. 

Don't get me wrong, the beer is awesome. They don't have a huge selection of beer, but whatever they do have is very good. The food here is expensive for a "food-truck" type of food, so try to come here not on an empty stomach. You shouldn't drink with an empty stomach anyway. I had the 2 sausages combo with pretzel for $18. The 1L beer is about $10. Sausages was ok, pretzel was good. Beer was excellent. 

So wear a jacket, layer, prepare to wait in line, bring lots of friend, come with good stories to tell and just be loud. Don't bring your date here. Unless it's a group thang and you like to talk to random groups of the same type of people.

excerpts: Once you order, don't forget to grab a pretzel or bratwurst basket to go with your with a tasty beverage.
pretzel.author: Kori M.
pretzel.review:
Since this city seems to have a huge lack of restaurants/bars with nice outdoor patios, this place is a little gem in my opinion. With giant tables (that are to be shared with strangers and friends alike) overlooking the small park in Hayes Valley, the Biergarten makes a perfect destination for a sunny afternoon.

After dark, they turn on the hanging lights above. This would give the place a romantic atmosphere, if it weren't for people shouting "chug, chug, chug!!!" around you. 

Yes, the line to the bar can get a little long, but use that time to make a new friends with some of the folks waiting there with you. Once you order, don't forget to grab a pretzel or bratwurst basket to go with your with a tasty beverage.

excerpts: The frankfurter on a pretzel roll was very tasty and my beer was excellent.
I felt like a warrior drinking from one of the liter steins.
The only downside, and it's a big one, is the wait time for a drink or a re-fill.
If you plan on having more than one drink, keep someone in line at all times because it took 30+ min to get our first drink and the line kept getting longer and longer.
pretzel.author: Marcin M.
pretzel.review: Great outdoor beer garden style place to drink delicious beers and eat delicious German food.  Picnic table style seating so chances are you'll be sharing a table with strangers given the limited seating.  The frankfurter on a pretzel roll was very tasty and my beer was excellent.  I felt like a warrior drinking from one of the liter steins.  The only downside, and it's a big one, is the wait time for a drink or a re-fill.  If you plan on having more than one drink, keep someone in line at all times because it took 30+ min to get our first drink and the line kept getting longer and longer.

excerpts: After sampling the three beer selections, we chose our beers and sat down to share our tasty pork delights from Chairman Bao in addition to an order of bratwursts, sauerkraut and pretzel.
As I dipped the chewy pretzel into the spicy mustard, I reflected that this is an ideal date place.
After all, it's a non-pretentious outdoor dining where you feast on beer, sauerkraut, and sausages.
Afterwards, if you are in the mood for something sweet, Smitten Ice Cream is right across the street where you have to opportunity to see liquid nitrogen at work.
pretzel.author: Sophie C.
pretzel.review:
On a spontaneous decision to check out Off the Grid-Proxy, we stumbled upon the gem Biergarten. After sampling the three beer selections, we chose our beers and sat down to share our tasty pork delights from Chairman Bao in addition to an order of bratwursts, sauerkraut and pretzel.

excerpts: Pretzel was good, the horseradish was a nice compliment.
Seating is limited and although the wait wasn't bad when we went at 5pm, the line was super long as I was leaving.
Had the cider beer which was delish and heard no complaints about the others on tap as well.
Definitely will be back.
pretzel.author: Cassidy D.
pretzel.review: Really fun vibe! ! You really feel like you're at an outdoor pub in Germany. The food was fantastic. The sliders were literally the best sliders I've ever had. Pretzel was good, the horseradish was a nice compliment. Seating is limited and although the wait wasn't bad when we went at 5pm, the line was super long as I was leaving. Had the cider beer which was delish and heard no complaints about the others on tap as well. Definitely will be back.

excerpts: I've taken every person that's visited me to this beer garden, shared seeded pretzels, pickles, and the occasional pretzel-wich, and had many great afternoons here.
It's a shame
this place closes so early (especially on Sundays), but it's completely understandable based on the neighborhood and outdoor location.
Make sure to dress warmly, and keep an eye out for the friendly staff that come by with cozy blankets at night!
pretzel.author: Amy C.
pretzel.review:
I. Love. This. Place. 

The first night I moved to San Francisco, my friends and I were exhausted from lugging furniture all day and decided to check out the neighborhood.  After a hearty meal at Patxi's, we stumbled upon the cute public space and were drawn to the twinkling lights above the Biergarten.  I've been back several times ever since.

I've tried a few of their beers (the selection isn't vast, so this isn't difficult), and my favorite is their Schneider Weisse.  I've taken every person that's visited me to this beer garden, shared seeded pretzels, pickles, and the occasional pretzel-wich, and had many great afternoons here.  It's a shame this place closes so early (especially on Sundays), but it's completely understandable based on the neighborhood and outdoor location.  Make sure to dress warmly, and keep an eye out for the friendly staff that come by with cozy blankets at night!

excerpts: As for snacks, I especially love the pretzel.
It's warm and soft and served with mustard.
The second time I came here, the pretzel/bread maker happened to be on vacation so we were pretty bummed.
Hopefully the next time I visit, there will be pretzels with my beer!
pretzel.author: Charlene P.
pretzel.review: This is such a great idea!  Outdoor socializing with beer and snacks.  On cold days/nights, they offer blankets to keep you nice and warm.  I've been here a couple times.  The first time I came here, they had a german band in costume which was pretty cool.  They offer a nice selection of beer on tap and some in bottle and a good selection of snacks.  You can choose either a 1/2 Liter or 1 Liter of beer.  As for snacks, I especially love the pretzel.  It's warm and soft and served with mustard.  Perfect combo with a nice glass of Schneider Weisse.  The second time I came here, the pretzel/bread maker happened to be on vacation so we were pretty bummed.  Hopefully the next time I visit, there will be pretzels with my beer!

excerpts: We ordered the bratwurst basket which includes 2 bratwurst, sauerkraut and a soft pretzel.
Oh and yummy pork belly sandwiches (2 mini to an order)!
Oh and of course a Black Logger!
I feel like I'm in Germany!
Extra
plus, I love the friendly staff.
Oh yes, they are so well equipped...
outdoor kitchen
and there are even very clean outdoor bathrooms (after all that beer!).
pretzel.author: Jay S.
pretzel.review: it's raining but who cares when you are at a fun beer garden right in the middle of Hayes valley. What a great idea. Outdoor seating with umbrellas on most tables and warm blankets just in case you need one. We ordered the bratwurst basket which includes 2 bratwurst, sauerkraut and a soft pretzel. Oh and yummy pork belly sandwiches (2 mini to an order)! Oh and of course a Black Logger! I feel like I'm in Germany! Extra plus, I love the friendly staff. Oh yes, they are so well equipped... outdoor kitchen and there are even very clean outdoor bathrooms (after all that beer!).

excerpts: We had an order of pickles and a pretzel while waiting in line, and later the sausages and sauerkraut.
I'm guessing it was the latter that did us in.
This is such a shame, because the food was surprisingly good.
pretzel.author: Brett L.
pretzel.review:
It really pains me to give this rating, but my girlfriend and I both got sick after eating here. We had an order of pickles and a pretzel while waiting in line, and later the sausages and sauerkraut. I'm guessing it was the latter that did us in. This is such a shame, because the food was surprisingly good. Fortunately, it was not too bad, and neither of us missed work.

Had it not been for the incident with the food, I'd give this place 3.5 stars, maybe 4. The biggest problem is the lines. I don't mind waiting to get into the place (the guy at the door (the owner?) was really friendly and helpful), but you have to go back into that long line to order another beer, as there is no table service nor a separate line for customers already inside. I'd also deduct a 1/2 star for lack of variety. They had Schneider Weisse (yay!), but the other two beers were ok. The Radler is way too sweet for me, but that's a personal preference I suppose. Those were the only options the day we were there.

So my take on this place? If you don't mind the lines, this is a lovely place to spend a sunny afternoon. The communal outdoor benches are great. I'll personally avoid the food, but might be back for a beer. With Schmidt's and Walzwerk not far away, however, I might just go to one of those places to get a better selection of beer.

excerpts: The banana knot, pretzel with banana, hazelnut butter and honey was delicious.
Very enjoyable with a larger group of people on a sunny day.
pretzel.author: Antonio V.
pretzel.review: Had to wait in line for about 40 minutes but it was well worth it. The banana knot, pretzel with banana, hazelnut butter and honey was delicious. Very enjoyable with a larger group of people on a sunny day.

excerpts: I loved the beet salad and the pretzel.
Definitely will head back on a nice day!
pretzel.author: Gina C.
pretzel.review: Great atmosphere, great beers, great food and an awesome place to go on a warm day. Keep in mind that it opens at 3 pm and make sure to get there by about 2:45 if you want a table. The menu is pretty limited but everything we ordered was great... I loved the beet salad and the pretzel. Definitely will head back on a nice day!

excerpts: yes the pretzel is just as good as the other reviews say it is.
so must get something with their pretzel in it!!!!!
pretzel.author: JY L.
pretzel.review:
love the atmosphere!!!! outdoor drinking with blankets and lights.  

I can't pronounce or spell the beers we got but let's just say the place is a beer lover paradise. The food was pretty good too!!! 

yes the pretzel is just as good as the other reviews say it is.  so must get something with their pretzel in it!!!!!

excerpts: there's a decent selection of food--definitely try the pretzel, cheese knot, anything pretzel-related.
this would be great on a warm sunny day, but i would alsoo like to come at night because they have super cute light bulbs hanging across.
pretzel.author: Veronica L.
pretzel.review: I really like this place! Is it weird that I'd like to have my wedding reception here? Love the layout--it's really, as everyone says, an old parking lot, and you order your beer/food in like a trailer. you have a wide selection of beers and some are in a 0.5 or 1 liter so come on an empty stomach. there's a decent selection of food--definitely try the pretzel, cheese knot, anything pretzel-related. this would be great on a warm sunny day, but i would alsoo like to come at night because they have super cute light bulbs hanging across.

excerpts: Had a liter of Pils, the lardo on brown bread (sublime!), the charctuerie on a pretzel knot (perfectly salty) and a pretzel with mustard and horseradish (just the right chew) and a just-right pickle.
Sitting outside with great food and a lot of beer on a beautiful and sunny San Francisco day is about as good as it gets.
The wait was well worth it and the location perfect for people watching (most were actually watching us inside the fence....)
pretzel.author: Susan F.
pretzel.review: Yummo!  Had a liter of Pils, the lardo on brown bread (sublime!), the charctuerie on a pretzel knot (perfectly salty) and a pretzel with mustard and horseradish (just the right chew) and a just-right pickle.  Sitting outside with great food and a lot of beer on a beautiful and sunny San Francisco day is about as good as it gets.  The wait was well worth it and the location perfect for people watching (most were actually watching us inside the fence....)

My main complaint was that they ran out of pretzels while we were there.

All the food was yummy and they have specials every day too. Really diligent staff that was always walking around picking up empty glasses, food trays, and offering blankets. What a cool concept. excerpts: And the pretzel was also yummy.
pretzel.author: Courtney J.
pretzel.review: Great place for a drink and a bite to eat with friends.   After we ordered and sat down, I felt like I was back in Berlin.  I love this they have all German beers on tap available in 0.5L or 1L mugs.  And the pretzel was also yummy.

pretzel.author: Siddika P.
pretzel.review: This place was so trendy and I was actually expecting something better. You need to wait a long line to have beer. There are few pretzel like things to eat -- not great. Nice to sit and drink outdoors but there are lots of other places you can do that. There is not much special about this place.

excerpts: What I got in return for my $5 was a COLD seeded pretzel with dollops of mustard and nostril-searing horseradish.
seeded pretzel.author: Patrick H.
seeded pretzel.review:
Go for the bier, stay for the outdoor drinking experience. But eat elsewhere. 

Let me explain...

The beer choices are good and you can get them in 1/2 or 1 Litre sizes, but you'll have to wait in a long line before getting to quench your thirst. The people taking your order are friendly, answer your questions, and don't rush you despite the line that keeps growing behind you (it takes a while to pour a litre of beer!).

Once you have your beer in hand, find a picnic table, kick back, and get merry.

And if you happen to get hungry, I'd visit the food trucks parked around the corner before buying food here again. On to the hugely disappointing snacks:
I was looking forward to having a nice, warm German pretzel. What I got in return for my $5 was a COLD seeded pretzel with dollops of mustard and nostril-searing horseradish. F that.

Still hungry, I ordered a brat & sauerkraut for $9. Tasty, but no bun so it wasn't as filling as I was hoping. Hey, at least the brat was hot. Still, $9 for a brat is kinda crazy. Is there a ballgame going on here? They must be made from organic, virgin, nitrite-free, vegan-diet pork to justify it.

Given their overhead (or lack thereof), I'd expect lower prices across the board. But since the crowds keep on coming, I doubt they'll change anything.

pickle.review: I absolutely love this place but there's always a huge line when it's nice out. I'd recommend ordering everything you plan to eat/drink the first time you stand in line because the line is consistently 15-20 minutes. Also if you order 1 pickle you get like 10

pickle.review:

excerpts: Like everything in the city expect a line but, if you have cash you can grab a pretzel or a pickle while you wait.
pickle.author: Kristen R.
pickle.review:
Great place to go and enjoy the patio. Like everything in the city expect a line but, if you have cash you can grab a pretzel or a pickle while you wait. Prepare to sit with strangers and have a giant beer. 

The food prices are reasonable and most everything was good. The knot was my fave but, the mustard was intense and dominated the taste of the braut and deviled eggs.

All and all worth the wait it takes.

excerpts: With only a couple lagers to choose from and a small selection of bar snacks (think: pretzels, sausages, pickle jars), Biergarten serves you mostly for a cool outdoor atmosphere when you want to impress your friends from out of town who aren't ready for the grit and grime of a typical SF dive bar.
If you want more to taste, I would suggest just going to Suppenkuche down the street instead for a full meal and a better selection of beers.
pickle.author: Marina L.
pickle.review:
Biergarten has that classic outdoor patio vibe that's great for hanging out with your favorite homies over a few pints that makes you feel like a viking (the pints make my arms feel tiny and weak). As a derivative of Suppenkuche, it's an extension of the German joint in terms of space, only featuring a much more limited menu. With only a couple lagers to choose from and a small selection of bar snacks (think: pretzels, sausages, pickle jars), Biergarten serves you mostly for a cool outdoor atmosphere when you want to impress your friends from out of town who aren't ready for the grit and grime of a typical SF dive bar. If you want more to taste, I would suggest just going to Suppenkuche down the street instead for a full meal and a better selection of beers. If you're looking to just chill on a rare sunny SF day, this is the place.

Things to know:
- On really nice weekends, get there when it opens (3pm) to snag a table before it gets too crowded
- They don't have space-heaters, so get cozy with some blankets provided in the far corner
- They have 2 stalls of clean restrooms, so drink to your heart's content!

excerpts: The real advantage is having a pretzel, a pickle, or a brat outside on long picnic tables with groups of up to ten to a table.

pickle.review:
Finally been to the Biergarten - it's across the street from me but it took me 10 months to try it! Good thing for half days. And a testament to how popular it is!

Beer selection is okay -- you could always go to suppenkuche for beer without a wait. The real advantage is having a pretzel, a pickle, or a brat outside on long picnic tables with groups of up to ten to a table.

They carded a friend of ours who was over 40. He didn't have his ID because we were doing a company offsite before that required running. They didn't care. Color me ignorant, but that feels like some pretty unempowered employees IMHO. Are we in sf?

Die Bier garten habt real estate but that's it in my opinion. Outside drinking and food and ample space? Go to the falafel place.

bratwurst.author: Richard J.
bratwurst.review:
Long gone are the dive bars and beergardens of yore. In their stead lie establishments such as Biergarten Hayes Valley! Pretty good and overpriced...

Let me explain. I enjoy this place. The service was friendly and prompt. I got the burger with arugula Swiss and deli mustard, for $8, and a liter of German style beer for $20. That's right, each ounce of this beer cost me approximately $0.59. *sips slowly* Aaahhhh...

The burger was a slider. There's no way around it. My friend got a bratwurst which he described as a Costco hot dog in a sourdough bun that was toasted on the outside only, which was $11. I anticipate his review will yield one star if he doesn't pass out from hunger before posting it. I personally am having a friend pick up food for me so that I survive a bar crawl tonight.

Overall, delicious experience for me, but the prices reflect a level of inflation we shouldn't hit for another 27 years.

bratwurst.review:
I've lived in Germany for a month before and this place really brought me back to some good times.  I'm not a huge drinker (but come on just get the big liter for the snaps) so I'll focus my review on the food, which I felt was pretty legit.  

I loved the bratwurst, especially with the potatoes.  The pork belly sliders are a must.  Throw in a pretzel into the mix!  The Wednesday burger looked so amazing that I felt compelled to get it, but surprisingly not my fav.  Just get more sliders to share!

The outdoor seating is really cute.  When it started to get chilly, a really nice lady brought out these really heavy blankets for us.

neither Currywurst and we don't eat our Pretzels (Brezen) warm.

For an authentic Biergarten I'd expect a bit more than just a parking lot with a fence.

bratwurst.author: Maria H.
bratwurst.review:
Hi from your German that moved to the U.S. a few years ago.

+ The beer selection is good (I saw a few posts that say it doesn't have enough but even Biergarten in Germany have like 5 - 6 different types -- I don't understand why you'd like 30 different beer types). Order Andechs if you don't know what you like.
+ The tables and benches are typically German and it's outdoors. That's the only reason I come back.
+ They offer Glühwein in the winter.

- Unfortunately, the food is not German at all. Some other people said it's authentic but trust me: it's not. We would never eat Bratwurst in the way they serve it, neither Currywurst and we don't eat our Pretzels (Brezen) warm. I wouldn't even like it if it was an American restaurant.
- There is no decoration at all. For an authentic Biergarten I'd expect a bit more than just a parking lot with a fence.
- It's expensive and the food is not worth the money. 
- The local crowd is usually the typical tech crowd that you see everywhere which is why it doesn't feel like a real Biergarten at all (at least to me because I grew up with them).

Overall, I'm still going there because they sell my favorite beer and I like to drink beer outside but I wouldn't come there for the food or the atmosphere.

excerpts: Went with the wheat beer and the bratwurst.
The beer was very good and the bratwurst was surprisingly very delicious.
The mustard and garlic really made it.
Would def come back!
bratwurst.author: Linda H.
bratwurst.review: Nice way to kick off Oktoberfest. Gets really crowded really fast. A nice not huge selection of beers. Went with the wheat beer and the bratwurst. The beer was very good and the bratwurst was surprisingly very delicious. The mustard and garlic really made it. Would def come back!

excerpts: My favorite sausages are the Bratwurst and the Currywurst; they are both authentic and filling.
bratwurst.author: Regina L.
bratwurst.review:
The Biergarten should be a home run in my books because of the great German beer, food, and outdoor space. When the sun is out (and even when it's not), you can bet that people flock to this place to sit out in the sun and drink delicious beer. Biergarten is a great use of space, as they utilize shipping containers and make an empty lot a fun place for people to congregate. Their beer list is extensive and offers something for everything. And the food, omg, I absolutely love German food, and they do not disappoint. My favorite sausages are the Bratwurst and the Currywurst; they are both authentic and filling. The pretzels and pickled deviled eggs are great for sharing (although I hate having to share my pretzel). 

The problem, you ask? That LINE. The line of all lines. In order to get a beer or order food, you have to wait in a line that snakes practically across the lot. And it's not a fast line either, especially when you're thirsty or your friends are already seated and waiting for you. I wish there was a better system for ordering; normally I would just order two drinks at a time, but the beer would quickly get warm sitting in the sun (and no one likes warm beer). So there you have it: a lively spot to meet friends, great beer and food, but the most buzzkill line ever.

I like Hayes Valley. 

I like deviled eggs. 

I like beer.

I love bratwurst (Y'all should know that by now!).

I love people watching while stuffing my face.

bratwurst.review: The Biergarten is a very authentic and fun place to go in Hayes Valley! Especially on a weekend. I went with two friends and I got a beer and a bratwurst. The beer came in a big mug and the bratwurst came with curried potatoes which were very tasty as well as Dijon mustard and minced garlic. The bratwurst was super juicy and melted in your mouth. And the beer was good too!

excerpts: Bratwurst was great!!
bratwurst.author: Elysia M.
bratwurst.review:
This place is so cool! I've always seen it and have wanted to stop in for a drink but now that I actually have, I will definitely be returning. 

I went on a Thursday night with some co workers, not expecting to have too grand of a time. But it turned out to be so great! Just the atmosphere of things was awesome, everyone of the customers seemed like they were genuinely having a good time and would like to chat with you, kind of a Portland feel!

The venue itself was super cute with tables to share and sit with others and like at festivals. The lighting wasn't too dim at night with their string lights, was just perfect!

Although the beer selection isn't too large, it was really good! Tried multiple and they had a lot of good german beers, for a good price! The food was Great. Authentic and very tastey! Bratwurst was great!!

Now they don't get 4 stars because of two things, the employees weren't too kind, kind of grumps to be honest, and it got really cold! They should get heating lamps! But they did have blankets, which is nice... But what if the person before had lice?! 

Either way, I'll definitely go back.

excerpts: The bratwurst and the deviled eggs were quite good too.
Can't wait to go back.
bratwurst.author: Niloy B.
bratwurst.review: This is in one of my favorite hangout areas in the city. The ambience is excellent. There is always a steady line for the beer. There are several good choices daily. I got a red ale westfalia. It was delicious. The bratwurst and the deviled eggs were quite good too. Can't wait to go back.

excerpts: Got a pretzel and a bratwurst.
Bratwurst came with curry potatoes, dark mustard and horseradish.
Was excellent with beer.
They also have pretzel knots and deviled eggs.
Probably will try those next time.
Wish they opened a bit earlier and added some heater after sun down!
Taking a star down for that, otherwise this was a definite 5 star!!!
Definitely coming back again!
bratwurst.author: Vikram C.
bratwurst.review:
Zehr Gut!!!
Excellent place right in the middle of SF with the feel of the original biergartens in Germany! 0.5L & 1L mugs of draft.. (of course, the review is not biased cos of that... ;) :P )
They had 4 different beers on draft ranging from a Helles to a Dopplebock and then a few bottles and also housemade mulled wine. 8$ for the 0.5L and $16 for the 1L mug of helles, obviously I had to get the larger mug. :) 
There's not a lot of seating and its picnic style shared benches. So late in the afternoon, seating wasn't an issue. But it does get busy at times and the line to order food goes out on the street. Also FYI, they did not have propane heaters. So once the sun goes down, be ready to bring on those jackets.
The food options are pretty good. Got a pretzel and a bratwurst. Bratwurst came with curry potatoes, dark mustard and horseradish. Was excellent with beer. They also have pretzel knots and deviled eggs. Probably will try those next time.
Wish they opened a bit earlier and added some heater after sun down! Taking a star down for that, otherwise this was a definite 5 star!!! Definitely coming back again!

excerpts: The Bratwurst was delicious, but I wish that it came with more potatoes, because it was a bit hard to eat one whole Bratwurst all on its own without anything else to balance out the taste of meat.
bratwurst.author: Lydia T.
bratwurst.review:
A friend and I shared the Bratswurst basket. The Bratwurst was delicious, but I wish that it came with more potatoes, because it was a bit hard to eat one whole Bratwurst all on its own without anything else to balance out the taste of meat. The potatoes that the basket did come with were super tasty, and was coated in a very delicious sauce. 

We came in during the evening, and the ambience out here is very fun and cheerful. Since San Francisco experiences many cold nights, there are large warm blankets available for people to wrap themselves into or use to cover their legs. I would love to try this place out again during the afternoon, and try more food here next time.

excerpts: I recommend ordering the Weihenstephaner Original Lager, Bratwurst and the Pork Belly sliders.
bratwurst.author: Shannon R.
bratwurst.review:
Great place with an energetic atmosphere. Be sure to get there early so a friend can snag a communal table while you wait in line to get your (liter of) beer. Also have everyone's ID in your hand when you go get drinks; it's required. All the beers are yummy and the food is to die for. I recommend ordering the Weihenstephaner Original Lager, Bratwurst and the Pork Belly sliders.

Biergarten also has a sister restaurant called Suppenküche that you should go check out!

excerpts: A few other items I recommend are the pork belly sliders, the bratwurst platter, pretzel and the gnome burger.
The curry potatoes that accompany the bratwurst are great.
They have good German beer!
Outdoor communal seating allows for socialization amongst other patrons.
I said it once
and I'll say it again, I love Biergarten.

bratwurst.review: I love Biergarten and so has everyone I've brought here. I also like the concept of reusing old shipping containers and turning them into this beer garden. Every time I'm here I must get the deviled eggs. A few other items I recommend are the pork belly sliders, the bratwurst platter, pretzel and the gnome burger. The curry potatoes that accompany the bratwurst are great. They have good German beer! Outdoor communal seating allows for socialization amongst other patrons. I said it once and I'll say it again, I love Biergarten.

excerpts: BEST BRATWURST I'VE HAD IN THE CITY!
bratwurst.author: Emily D.
bratwurst.review:
Its awesome! But how could authentic German beer be bad, really? Ok, well, the one caveat-- there were babies here. Babies at a bar? Not the best idea.

BUT THEIR SAUSAGE! OMG. BEST BRATWURST I'VE HAD IN THE CITY! And I go for sausage quite a bit. 

Fun fact- don't come here on a tuesday. Despite the fact Yelp says they're open, they aren't, and you and your roommate will be pissed you're standing around outside a chain link fence and dirt area sans beer. True story.

excerpts: The bratwurst with saurkraut was delicious of course, bursting with clear meaty juice.
bratwurst.author: Jennifer W.
bratwurst.review:
It seems like we've been waiting a long time for this place. Too bad the opening of this place has been set back time and time again because it's no longer summer. Rainy season is upon us and they will be closed. I love Suppenkuche to begin with so I knew there was no way this couldn't be good.

There's a cash only line for pretzels and pickles. The larger line is for everything, including beer and sausages. Though this line can take a long time, it's not that bad if you get yourself a liter to last yourself a while until the next one. I often find myself going to the bar many times throughout the night at a bar, but here, I can settle down with a large liter stein. The pretzel was pretty good, but not the best German pretzel I've had. It was a thin style with mustard and horseradish, comes in seeded or non-seeded versions. The bratwurst with saurkraut was delicious of course, bursting with clear meaty juice.

There are two restrooms that are very clean and roomy. Sinks are smartly located outside. The drinking area is composed of thin picnic tables and thin benches positioned in a radial fashion around a tree. The tables are really close to each other, so you can literally be trapped in the center with the tree if you exit the wrong way. Otherwise, I love the coziness of good company and warm yellow lights on a nippy evening. This really, is a biergarten.

The huge, glaring drawback is that the line to get into the place at all gets long. I understand that this must be nice once you're inside to not have people crowding around you for seats. But still. It's a funny situation. I felt like I was waiting at the border to go to the promise land and that bouncer was US customs. Either that or it felt like prison, but where being in prison was a good thing. Several other people from the inside were at the chain link fence consoling their friends on the outside. I know how this feels because I was on the outside.

excerpts: wurst / bratwurst were delicious.
Had the wheat beer too which was pretty good.
bratwurst.author: Andrew C.
bratwurst.review:
We came on a Sunday afternoon at around 1pm when they opened. Soon after, all the tables filled up and the lineup for beer and food reached 45 minutes. 

Food: curry wurst / bratwurst were delicious. Had the wheat beer too which was pretty good. Overall, pretty decent. 

Setting: picnic bench-type seating with no overhead shading. Bring sunblock or cover up. Lots of us got burned.  There are two separate washrooms for men and women though I was told there's a urinal in the women's washroom. 

Summary: prepare to wait. Bring sunblock. Go early for a table.

excerpts: Bratwurst, pretzels, deviled eggs, etc.
It doesn't even compare with what you'd find at a festival in Germany, but it's good enough to balance out your beer.
I got a Frankfurter, which is served with mustard and sauerkraut.
Although it was pretty tasty, it's not worth $8.
bratwurst.author: Dmitriy S.
bratwurst.review:
In order to avoid the ridiculously overpriced SF Oktoberfest, my friends and I headed to Biergarten to celebrate the first day of the world's greatest drinking holiday. Lines were out the door (or rather fence), but that didn't stop us.

Biergarten is a very simple concept. You get your beer, sit down at a table with your buds, and simply enjoy the blissful world of Hayes Valley around you. Aside from lights and umbrellas, there's no decorations. 

Beer selection is minimal, but high quality. For Oktoberfest, they had around 5 different beers, including the famous but mediocre Hofbräu Oktoberfestbier and the delightful Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest-Märzen. $7 for 1/2L and $14 for 1L. Pretty decent prices for high quality beer. 

In addition to beer, you get your choice of typical German street foods. Bratwurst, pretzels, deviled eggs, etc. It doesn't even compare with what you'd find at a festival in Germany, but it's good enough to balance out your beer. I got a Frankfurter, which is served with mustard and sauerkraut. Although it was pretty tasty, it's not worth $8. Most of the food items are heavily overpriced, so I advise you eat before coming here. 

The venue gets crowded very easily, especially on a weekend or such a big holiday, so scoping out seats is a must. They could easily put more tables in here. Also, since you're outside, be ready for the temperature changes. 

Overall, a great place to enjoy one of Germany's most vital contributions to American society.

excerpts: Get the pickled deviled eggs, bratwurst with sauerkraut, and pretzels to go around.
The horseradish only encouraged me to drink more beer!
bratwurst.author: Samantha L.
bratwurst.review:
Took friends visiting out of town to Biergarten for what i think is a very SF experience, arriving promptly at 3pm to find a line formed around the entire Biergarten's fence. Judging from the number of people and the side of the area i was afraid we weren't going to find a table. That worry quickly washed away when i realized we were actually standing in the food line and not purely an entry line. Once they open the doors anyone can walk right in and bypass the line to stake out a table! I highly suggesting splitting your party up - half find a table and half stay in line to order.

I truly believe i spend half my time waiting in lines in the city. Most of the time it's to eat at places like this biergarten where reservations aren't accepted. Almost 45 minutes later we finally place our order! Order all your drinks and food the first round because you will NOT want to get back in line.

The atmosphere is perfect for a laid back group who share a love of tasty beers and german food. It's trendy, in the middle of hayes valley, neighboring Smitten's ice cream and a Blue Bottle kiosk.The wind picks up like mad as the sun starts to dim. Drinking more beer doesn't always keep us warm enough! Luckily they know this at Biergarten and provide heavy duty blankets for us wimps in SF who can't handle a little cold.

Get the pickled deviled eggs, bratwurst with sauerkraut, and pretzels to go around. The horseradish only encouraged me to drink more beer!

excerpts: There are plenty of places to drink beer on a patio (and even get a bratwurst) in the city, not sure why this place is so special.
Brats were good though, I'll concede to that.
bratwurst.author: Kathryn P.
bratwurst.review: Came here for a friends birthday on a sunny Saturday when everyone else in SF decided to do the same. It was SO crowded! The servers were aloof and overworked and too busy. We waited in a long, 30 minute line for a beer. Yes, I know waiting in line is what we "do" in San Francisco but is anyone over this yet? Just me? I don't get it. There are plenty of places to drink beer on a patio (and even get a bratwurst) in the city, not sure why this place is so special.  Brats were good though, I'll concede to that.

excerpts: They were out of the Bratwurst, but we ordered pork sliders, beef tongue, Asahi
(BTW, it was Japanese themed today...
is this a Japan/Germany/Axis thing?) and Edelweiss.
bratwurst.author: Reyz A.
bratwurst.review:
Didn't know about this place till my friend invited me down. I always pass this place off of 101 on to Octavia. It's kind of like, Munich meets steel shipping container land. The bathrooms, the vending areas, shipping containers. Luckily the seating/picnic tables (which BTW, after 4pm is nonexistent) are not.

It was a pretty nice day in San Francisco, OK it was 56F. Line already formed by 4...it took about 15 minutes to get to the front of the queue. They were out of the Bratwurst, but we ordered pork sliders, beef tongue, Asahi (BTW, it was Japanese themed today...is this a Japan/Germany/Axis thing?) and Edelweiss. All for about $40bucks.

Lucky for us, I found some milk crates to fashion a makeshift table and seats. Ate our dinner, froze our butts and a couple left a table, and we jumped on it.  Overall a very nice experience to chat, eat and drink a brew or five.

excerpts: The bratwurst and potatoes with horseradish and mustard was really great.
bratwurst.author: Jeff S.
bratwurst.review:
We first noticed the line and crowded picnic tables filled with twenty something's drinking beer out of small, medium and large steins.

This fun and lively outdoor restaurant in the Hayes area of SF had a good selection of draft German beers and also had great food. The bratwurst and potatoes with horseradish and mustard was really great. Their pretzels with mustard were also delicious.

Give this place a try and dress warmly or find a sunny day. The area shopping on Hayes street nearby is also worth the trip there.

excerpts: Excellent homemade veggie sliders, delicious beet salad and a full of flavor (and sauerkraut) bratwurst on a pretzel roll.
bratwurst.author: Jason B.
bratwurst.review:
Tell me why.

One reason why Germany's Paul Van Dyk is awesome: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2mCQEM3FugM

Few reasons why German Biergarten is awesome: Excellent homemade veggie sliders, delicious beet salad and a full of flavor (and sauerkraut) bratwurst on a pretzel roll.

Plus homemade pickles and a Weihenstephaner lager so light and easy to drink that there was a bit of regret on this warm(ish) July night for not getting the large size.

Much like a packed PVD show get ready to be close with your neighbors as seating is all at communal tables. Atmosphere is lively but not too loud.

At roughly $25 a person this will not be a cheap excursion. But like a really good DJ experience a really good dining experience shouldn't be either.

Enjoy finding your own reasons for giving four stars.

excerpts: Excellent beer, bratwurst , deviled eggs and pork belly sliders.
Will try the other things on their menu soon!
bratwurst.author: Vaibhav S.
bratwurst.review: Excellent beer, bratwurst , deviled eggs and pork belly sliders. Will try the other things on their menu soon!

excerpts: I do want to try a bratwurst next time though.
bratwurst.author: Seema M.
bratwurst.review:
We came here yesterday (Thursday) for happy hour knowing that it had just opened last week and were expecting a crazy line. We strolled up around 6pm and there was no line to get in! Prime HH time and no line? :)

The line for beer was kinda long, but moved quickly. We ordered our steins of authentic hofbrau beer and found a picnic table for six. The crowd was really chill and respectful- no drunken, beer splashing younguns like I had expected. 

Food wise, I only had a pretzel. Overpriced and skipable. I do want to try a bratwurst next time though.

The staff were awesome.. cheerful and always making sure to shoot you a smile if you walked by them.

My brit husband who lived in Germany for a year gives Biergarten his beer loving stamp of approval- that makes it 5 stars alone right there.

excerpts: Their bratwurst basket is amazing and out of this world.
Sauerkraut was done perfectly.
bratwurst.author: Vanessa K.
bratwurst.review:
How is it possible that this place is packed, full, and the line for beer is almost around the corner at 3:30pm on a Sunday! Also considering they open at 3pm! Waited an hour for a beer, and it's not because the staff was moving slowly.  It appeared that people who were sitting down with their drinks, kept "cutting" and asking their friends who were waiting to get them more beers.  It feels like all the yuppies and hipster wannabe's trek it to hayes valley for the biergarten. Makes the place a little pretentious, and ignoring all of it, it's a great spot.

The beers are delicious and refreshing. Their bratwurst basket is amazing and out of this world. Sauerkraut was done perfectly. Love the pretzel, so soft and buttery.

excerpts: The bratwurst was amazing!
bratwurst.author: Rowena L.
bratwurst.review:
Been here twice in the past two weeks. Solid beer and food options, though slightly expensive. The bratwurst was amazing! 

There's nothing special about the place though, nothing that gives it any character, that's my main complaint. But overall it's a nice place to grab a beer outside on a nice day.

excerpts: Biergarten is exactly what its name implies, which is essentially an casual, fun outdoors gastropub that serves up an eclectric menu of German favorites like Bratwurst with fresh pretzles, maple syrup bacon bread pudding and wide array of drinks.
They are currently in the process of expanding the business so expect longer hours during the coming summer.
My friend and I had very fortunately stumbled upon Biergarten on our way to Chantal Guillon for macaroons, while waiting to be seated for dinner.
Both of us decided to return after our dinner reservation for late night (~7pm) spirits and snacks.
Although they were bustling with people around dinner time, the crowd began to thin down when we got there...
so there was no line and plenty of blankets, seating available.
bratwurst.author: Jenny Z.
bratwurst.review:
First of all, I have to say the whole concept of a "beer garden" is freaking awesome! Biergarten is exactly what its name implies, which is essentially an casual, fun outdoors gastropub that serves up an eclectric menu of German favorites like Bratwurst with fresh pretzles, maple syrup bacon bread pudding and wide array of drinks. They are currently in the process of expanding the business so expect longer hours during the coming summer. My friend and I had very fortunately stumbled upon Biergarten on our way to Chantal Guillon for macaroons, while waiting to be seated for dinner. Both of us decided to return after our dinner reservation for late night (~7pm) spirits and snacks. Although they were bustling with people around dinner time, the crowd began to thin down when we got there...so there was no line and plenty of blankets, seating available. And now I can proudly say that we were very happy with this decision!

There were 2 draft beers, 2 wines offerings that evening with several snacks. We decided on a white dessert wine, Pilsner and maple syrup bacon bread pudding to share. Everything was delicious, although the bread pudding was a little burnt at the bottom. Our Pilsner was big enough to be shared between the two of us. The warmly lit ambiance and complimentary blankets offered a nice shelter against the chilly winter night, overall making the scenery extremely sweet and comfortable...to the extent in which I ended up taking a short nap amidst our talking, snacking and drinking. Overall, it was the icing on top of great evening. Even though I didn't eat here...judging by the hungry bites my fellow customers were taking, the menus would definitely be worth exploring! The portions of their entrees may not filling enough for dinner but would serve as generous snacks to pair with drinks. I would say that this is a great place to for a laid-back hangout with friends on a weekday night, after work, or weekend. Good choice! Will definitely be returning with more friends

excerpts: At $7-10 a half liter and twice that for a full liter, and with food ranging from another $4-16 (from the knots to the baskets), Boyfriend and I ran up a $42 tab for a liter and a half of beer, a frankfurter with sauerkraut and a bratwurst with curried potatoes.
bratwurst.author: Anna W.
bratwurst.review:
On a beautiful Saturday afternoon after having spent all morning at the new Exploratorium acting like overgrown children, my group and I decided that we should reassert our adult-ness by grabbing liters of beer at the Biergarten. None of us had ever been, though we were all intrigued by the Yelp photos of mugs as big as our heads.

We got in line at about 2:45PM-2:50PM (right before they opened), and it had already just turned the corner on the block. They opened at 3PM on the dot, and people immediately either stampeded for the shady tables scattered through the courtyard or moved towards the beer line. By the time we got to the gate, most of the tables were already filled up, so we commandeered what looked like the only empty one left right by the gate itself.

Then, we waited for our beers. It took us about 30 minutes before we even got to order. Not that I ever really mind having to wait, but I should be waiting for beers that I can't find anywhere else. The beers that Biergarten had on tap were ones that you could find at most good, local liquor shops. But whatever, we were here to enjoy the Biergarten for what it was.

At $7-10 a half liter and twice that for a full liter, and with food ranging from another $4-16 (from the knots to the baskets), Boyfriend and I ran up a $42 tab for a liter and a half of beer, a frankfurter with sauerkraut and a bratwurst with curried potatoes. Everything was yummy, but not mouthwateringly rave-worthy.

Overall verdict: a very nice little spot with the potential to be very chill, but a little over-hyped. I would totally go back -- but at the prices they're charging and for what you get in return, I might just grab their beer only instead of snagging something to munch on, too.

They have blankets on every picnic table to warm up those cold bodies as well...
Fun casual atmosphere...
I can just imagine this place hopping in the day when the sun is actually shining.
Will be back (probably on a sunnier day).

bratwurst.author: Kimya P.
bratwurst.review:
Depending on the type of beer you choose a 1/2 liter can be anywhere from $6-8.  Their beer selection is limited in comparison to Suppenkuche but the Schneider weisse hits the spot. 

Bratwurst basket is perfect for two ($18): one sausage for each of you, a pretzel to share, and for dipping - horseradish (that WILL clear up your nose) and brown mustard. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/GfeaoeKtZh-57SFWgjPqnw?select=eFrF65UAqKeei47XHGh8oA)

The place is crowded, but as long as you are willing to make friends and share tables, it's great fun especially on a sunny Saturday afternoon.

excerpts: Oh and the bratwurst is so good ---
the mustard and sauerkraut served with it is fantastic.
bratwurst.author: Tysen C.
bratwurst.review:
Biergarten is super yummy! The beer is great and served in large quantities and the food is delicious. 

I'm a huge fan of the meat and cheese pretzel knots. Oh and the bratwurst is so good --- the mustard and sauerkraut served with it is fantastic. Also, homemade pickles and pickled carrots and the horseradish...drooling just thinking about it. 

Spend some time outside and enjoy what Beirgarten has to offer. I challenge you to not have a good time :P 

Next stop is the sister restaurant Suppenküche.

excerpts: My wife's favorite is the pork belly sliders, even though the bratwurst is my favorite.
bratwurst.author: LA H.
bratwurst.review:
Great place to drink with your friends on a sunny afternoon. Everyone's friendly, especially drunk on German beer! If it gets cold, large blankets are provided.

My friends and I have tried pints of different flavors of beer and they're all good. My wife's favorite is the pork belly sliders, even though the bratwurst is my favorite.

The lines can get extremely long on hotter days, but it's worth the wait if you have a friend or two to save some seats. We always try to make our way to Biergarten on warm weekends!

Plus: bathrooms on the back left!

excerpts: I ordered the bratwurst with a tangy sauerkraut and spicy brown mustard on pretzel bread.
When my sausage arrived it protruded out of both sides of the short pretzel bun, which kind of reminded me of the Scandinavian hot-dogs.
This allowed me to taste the meat, which was very tasty.
I was pleased to find the heaping amount of sauerkraut on top and paired with the mustard and freshly baked pretzel
bun
bratwurst.author: Natan O.
bratwurst.review:
I came to Biergarten for a quick bite but quickly made friends in the outdoor friendly atmosphere.  I ordered the bratwurst with a tangy sauerkraut and spicy brown mustard on pretzel bread.  When my sausage arrived it protruded out of both sides of the short pretzel bun, which kind of reminded me of the Scandinavian hot-dogs.  This allowed me to taste the meat, which was very tasty.  I was pleased to find the heaping amount of sauerkraut on top and paired with the mustard and freshly baked pretzel bun I was in heaven.  

I'm sad to say I didn't stay long enough to grab a beer but the selection looked more than adequate and I'm sure would go very well with the food.  I'll be back to try something else and drink up for last time!

excerpts: They shared a basket of sauerkraut, bratwurst, and yes, another pretzel.
Baby didn't get brats or beer, but fell asleep dreaming about them, so Mommy and Daddy were extra happy, too.
bratwurst.author: Peg S.
bratwurst.review: Baby became cranky when they couldn't get into Suppenkuche.  So, they brought baby to the biergarten for brats and beer. Daddy chugged down a lager.  Mommy wolfed down the pretzel.  They shared a basket of sauerkraut, bratwurst, and yes, another pretzel.  Baby didn't get brats or beer, but fell asleep dreaming about them, so Mommy and Daddy were extra happy, too.

They have the Hofbrau classic beer served in
the HB german bubble glass steins (1/2 and full liters).
The only problem is that this place is always crowded, which is good for business, but hard to find a seat.
Good atmosphere, and a great place to stop for a beer if the lines are short, and there are several nice eateries in the local area if you aren't in the mood for a wiener.

excerpts: I ordered the bratwurst with sauerkraut; the food was really good, however they should at least give two brats instead of only one if they charge $9.
The sauerkraut was one of the best i've ever tried... not like your typical type found at ballparks.
bratwurst.author: Ryan C.
bratwurst.review:
Came here sometime last fall with my friends who wanted to check it out.  The concept of the place is cool; they try to replicate the atmosphere of a German beer garden with authentic benches and mugs.  They even have blankets out; a good amenity to have given the chilly nights in San Francisco.

However, in terms of their food and drink, I have mixed feelings.  In all honesty, the food there is overpriced.  I ordered the bratwurst with sauerkraut; the food was really good, however they should at least give two brats instead of only one if they charge $9.  The sauerkraut was one of the best i've ever tried... not like your typical type found at ballparks.  My friend ordered the egg sandwich (costing $8) , and he was still hungry after finishing it.
On the other hand, their beers are moderately priced. A 1/2 liter will cost you around $6-8, and they have a good selection of beers. I tried the Stiegl Pilsner and it was great!

All in all, this place is definitely worth trying at least once, just pick an evening/night that's not too cold.

excerpts: we ordered the bratwurst with sauerkraut and that was pretty delish.
Later we asked the server as he was cleaning up our trays what he would recommend.
He said that the sliders (cow tongue and pork belly) were good.
I was thrown off when he said cow tongue
but I just bit the bullet and ate it.
It was pretty delicious on my part.
bratwurst.author: Brian L.
bratwurst.review:
My cousin showed me the Yelp page for Biergarten and I tinged at the thought of going here. Hipsters. Cold SF weather. (insert something crummy about SF). Was I wrong!

When I got here with my cousin and her friend I was expecting the line to stretch out into the sidewalk but it didn't, so the wait time was very reasonable. Also keep an eye out for a space opening up so you can sit down with your glorious liter of beer. When I went to order, the person working the taps was very friendly and helped me choose a beer, even offering me if I wanted to try some to make sure I would like it. 

We all got a liter of Edelweiss and that was enjoyable. As for the food (I'm not sure if it was because I was hungry or not) we ordered the bratwurst with sauerkraut and that was pretty delish. Later we asked the server as he was cleaning up our trays what he would recommend. He said that the sliders (cow tongue and pork belly) were good. I was thrown off when he said cow tongue but I just bit the bullet and ate it. It was pretty delicious on my part. Never know unless you try...

I also saw the reviews for Biergarten and saw some contradicting things. The one review saying they couldn't get a knife? There were knifes and forks a plenty! When we ran out of napkins we flagged down a server and he put in more napkins in the cup where it was organized with the forks and knives. And I'm not sick from the food...

Although it was my first time there, some pro-tips to follow by the next time I go:
1. Dress in layers (SF weather can get really cold and windy in an instant).
2. If you start getting cold, they lend out blankets, but get them before they lend them all out! 
3. Just get the liter. Don't skimp out on yourself.
3. It'll probably be better to come on a "off" day, as in Wednesday or Thursday probably when they open up or later in the evening. I went on a Wednesday at around 6:30PM and it looked like it was dying out around 8PM ish.
4. GO WITH FRIENDS!!!

excerpts: As for the food... loved the bratwurst!
It comes with dijon mustard, horseradish that'll singe your nose hairs, and a giant heap of sauerkraut.
Though I was bit confused why it had sooo much liquid in the baskets it is served in.
That could be drained out a little better.
Brats are moist and flavorful.
The kraut was great!
bratwurst.author: Chris T.
bratwurst.review:
Fun!  ... with a few caveats.

First, get there within 45 minutes of it opening, which is at 2:00pm. After that time period, you're gonna be hovering over the tables like a hawk looking for a spot to rest your big ass steins. If you see a small bench spot, go ahead and ask to squeeze in. Most folks will be friendly enough to scooch a bit for you and your friends (hopefully it's just 1 or 2 only). 

I'd definitely spring for an entire 1L stein.  You think you'd only be game for half a liter... but chances are you're gonna be having a fun time chatting with your friends and sitting al fresco on a warm afternoon... you'll want to stay longer and drink more.  And it sucks majorly to have to line up again... guarantee another 30 min wait.  

Speaking of the wait... they need another person behind the taps! 2 cashiers can take the orders and 1 tap master can be dispensing the golden goodness.  This can hurry along the wait a lot faster.  But honestly, that'd probably fill this up really fast and there really isn't enough seats for such a big crowd.

As for the food... loved the bratwurst!  It comes with dijon mustard, horseradish that'll singe your nose hairs, and a giant heap of sauerkraut.  Though I was bit confused why it had sooo much liquid in the baskets it is served in.  That could be drained out a little better.  Brats are moist and flavorful.  The kraut was great!  I ate it like it was a side salad!

Deviled eggs were pickled in beet juice... gave it a unique sweet tang.  I added a goop of horseradish to balance it out.  Hoo wee!

Waitresses are really fast with serving the food and they're always coming around to pick up your empty dishes/glasses.  They either do that to replenish for the bar or they want to retrieve those back before it ends up in some TimBuk2 bag (yoink!).

Also, you will no doubt bust out your bad German accent during your stay here.  Auf Wiedersehen!

excerpts: Once you order, don't forget to grab a pretzel or bratwurst basket to go with your with a tasty beverage.
bratwurst.author: Kori M.
bratwurst.review:
Since this city seems to have a huge lack of restaurants/bars with nice outdoor patios, this place is a little gem in my opinion. With giant tables (that are to be shared with strangers and friends alike) overlooking the small park in Hayes Valley, the Biergarten makes a perfect destination for a sunny afternoon.

After dark, they turn on the hanging lights above. This would give the place a romantic atmosphere, if it weren't for people shouting "chug, chug, chug!!!" around you. 

Yes, the line to the bar can get a little long, but use that time to make a new friends with some of the folks waiting there with you. Once you order, don't forget to grab a pretzel or bratwurst basket to go with your with a tasty beverage.

excerpts: No better way to conclude a beautiful morning surf than a cold liter of bier and and a piping hot bratwurst.
This fantastic little gem of a pub made my day.
The food was excellent and atmosphere was superb (sunny, courteous bar-staff).
Lastly, the line was not outrageous at all.
bratwurst.author: Connor S.
bratwurst.review: No better way to conclude a beautiful morning surf than a cold liter of bier and and a piping hot bratwurst. This fantastic little gem of a pub made my day. The food was excellent and atmosphere was superb (sunny, courteous bar-staff).  Lastly, the line was not outrageous at all.

excerpts: For the cost of aONE bratwurst and some sauerkraut, you can buy 2 packages of Aidelle's sausages (I'm just sayin').
bratwurst.author: Jason P.
bratwurst.review:
I like the conecpt of drinking outside (admirer of Zeitgeist).  They do sell half and full liter beers at reasonalbe prices.  It's still new so expect to wait on long lines but the turnover is pretty fast so by the time you get a beer/food, there will be a place to sit.

I must say, after ordering food with our beer, the cost skyrocketed.  The food is very expensive for what you get.  For the cost of aONE bratwurst and some sauerkraut, you can buy 2 packages of Aidelle's sausages (I'm just sayin').

Despite my 2 star rating, I will go back for the beer and ambience - but I will eat first.

excerpts: Otherwise the Bratwurst and Sauerkraut are damn good.
bratwurst.author: Rohan D.
bratwurst.review:
A nice little place by the park in Hayes Valley.

So if you like the taste of beer, don't get the one with Lemon Soda (Radler I believe), I thought it might be interesting but it was just a very smooth blue moonish like bear, very weak and not a very strong flavor at all. The other beers are better. If you want to avoid the taste of beer, then the Radler is a nice compromise.

Also, cash only + the beer won't get you drunk. It's the weakest stuff I've ever had.

Otherwise the Bratwurst and Sauerkraut are damn good. 

Try to grab some blankets.

excerpts: Bratwurst dog was excellent.
I had some shandy type of drink which was nice.
Of course if you go on a sunny day, lines will be long and there isn't always a place to sit.
Still the service is good.
bratwurst.author: Xteethx B.
bratwurst.review: Bratwurst dog was excellent. I had some shandy type of drink which was nice. Of course if you go on a sunny day, lines will be long and there isn't always a place to sit. Still the service is good.

excerpts: We ordered the bratwurst basket which includes 2 bratwurst, sauerkraut and a soft pretzel.
Oh and yummy pork belly sandwiches (2 mini to an order)!
Oh and of course a Black Logger!
I feel like I'm in Germany!
Extra
plus, I love the friendly staff.
Oh yes, they are so well equipped...
outdoor kitchen
and there are even very clean outdoor bathrooms (after all that beer!).
bratwurst.author: Jay S.
bratwurst.review: it's raining but who cares when you are at a fun beer garden right in the middle of Hayes valley. What a great idea. Outdoor seating with umbrellas on most tables and warm blankets just in case you need one. We ordered the bratwurst basket which includes 2 bratwurst, sauerkraut and a soft pretzel. egg sandwich.author: Ryan C.
egg sandwich.review:
Came here sometime last fall with my friends who wanted to check it out.  The concept of the place is cool; they try to replicate the atmosphere of a German beer garden with authentic benches and mugs.  They even have blankets out; a good amenity to have given the chilly nights in San Francisco.

However, in terms of their food and drink, I have mixed feelings.  In all honesty, the food there is overpriced.  I ordered the bratwurst with sauerkraut; the food was really good, however they should at least give two brats instead of only one if they charge $9.  The sauerkraut was one of the best i've ever tried... not like your typical type found at ballparks.  My friend ordered the egg sandwich (costing $8) , and he was still hungry after finishing it.
On the other hand, their beers are moderately priced. A 1/2 liter will cost you around $6-8, and they have a good selection of beers. I tried the Stiegl Pilsner and it was great!

All in all, this place is definitely worth trying at least once, just pick an evening/night that's not too cold.
